page.title: 01Marham - a Norfolk Village
page.content: Marham, formerly Cherry Marham, lies at the bottom of a chalk enscarpment running into peat clay fenland to the North-west, and sandy loam to the south-east. It gives rise to several natural springs which are pumped by the A.W.A. in a station at the centre of the village. The land is mainly agricultural, engaged in mixed, cattle and dairy farming but with some small woods, which are mainly deciduous. A few people work in agriculture, and the balance commute to the R.A.F. Station or the local towns. There are two small factories, one electrical, and the other a carrot processing station. The Norman Church is dedicated to the Holy Trinity. The present houses are built of brick and they are mainly of modern construction there being 50% bungalows in the village.
